Source for max height: Stace (1991); length of submerged lvs estimated from fact that does not flower when water deeper than 65 cm (Preston & Croft 1997)
Comment on life form: although a water plant, basic behaviour is as a rosette hemicryptophyte

Source for max height: half length in Stace (1997) "decumbent to ascending"

Comment on clonality: clonal growth is accompanied by almost no lateral spread

Source for max height: average of Stace (1997) and Aeschimann & Burdet (1994) - conf. by personal observation (MOH)

Comment on life form: According to CTW perennates by offsets, not by newly seeding; P & C (1994) regard it as annual.
Presumably dies back to base in winter

Source for max height: Stace (1997) - this is also leaf length, average of CTW (1962) & Stace (1997)

Comment on clonality: According to Crompton et al. (RDB account) regenerates from offset bulbs

Comment on life form: The height refers to the flowering stem, not the low rosettes that overwinter

Comment on clonality: may be widely spreading; it is regarded as inconveniently invasive by gardeners

Comment on life form: The buds for next year's growth are mostly below 25 cm.
Has creeping woody underground stem; above-ground overwintering shoots much shorter than flowering stem

Source for max height: Stace (1991) - biggest ones in Cambridge to 2.0 m (MOH, personal observation)

Comment on clonality: regenerates by means of stolons to form patches (CPE); these are subterranean (MOH, personal observation)

Source for max height: Stace (1997) says 60 cm; but Aeschimann & Burdet (1994) give 50 cm limit, Aizpuru et al. (1999) 40 cm, and Pearman et al. (2008) remark that it is exceptionally tall on Rum, to 0.5 m.

Comment on clonality: CTW imply that only C. macrophylla is far-creeping, but this is probably not true

Comment on life form: CTW say "annual or biennial"

Comment on clonality: a gregarious species (CTW)
sometimes forms clones but often rather short-lived

Comment on life form: CTW treat as a chamaephyte, but better as a hemicryptophyte, as it dies back to ground level in winter.

Source for max height: Typical maximum leaf length (MOH personal observation)

Comment on life form: not obvious why CTW treat it as sometimes a geophyte; almost always monocarpic (Heard, pers. Comm.)
"Occasionally perennating" - CTW
winter-green but dying back

Comment on clonality: CTW say it sometimes persists by root buds, but CPE say usually monocarpic

Comment on life form: Rich (1991) says "annual or biennial"

Comment on clonality: CPE say that it forms extensive clonal patches by means of stolons

Comment on life form: Rich (1991) says it can be annual or biennial.
Its claim to be a chamaephyte is the somewhat woody stock; the height refers to the flowering stem, not the ground-level stock

Comment on clonality: Spread occasionally by detached lateral buds developing on rhizome
Carrot-like tubers are roots; lateral spread is by underground stolons
Creeping stems which ramify locally at soil surface (CPE)
may produce stolons to 10 cm (Biol Flora, 1955); limited potential for clonal growth (J Ecol 91,19,2003)
Some genotypes produce stolons, others do not (Sell); epigeal or hypogeal (CPE); rarely produces bulbils (CPE)

Comment on life form: Definitely a chamaephyte; the overwintering bits are down below
Stace says "annual to perennial", but CTW say "rarely perennial"
perhaps genuinely intermediate; it depends on whether most stems die back

Comment on clonality: rooting of prostrate stems may occasionally result in clonal patches (CPE)

Comment on life form: basically hemicryptophyte; basal rosette is dominant, at least to begin with

Source for max height: Stace (1997) - this is also leaf length, average of CTW (1962) & Stace (1997)

Comment on clonality: main means of spread is rhizomes, but can regenerate from roots (CPE)

Comment on life form: a true geophyte; disappears well below ground in winter
Comment on clonality: underground organs probably mainly rhizomes (CPE equivocates on this)

Source for max height: CTW (1962) - but this is diameter of heads
Comment on clonality: anomalous; an annual forming extensive clones but not rooting

Name: Calluna vulgaris
Comment on life form: dwarf shrub

Name: Empetrum nigrum
Comment on life form: dwarf shrub

Name: Moneses uniflora
Comment on life form: It seems best to classify it as a wintergreen hemicryptophyte; the basic structure is a basal rosette

Name: Phyllodoce caerulea
Comment on life form: dwarf shrub

Name: Pyrola minor
Comment on life form: It seems best to classify it mainly as a wintergreen hemicryptophyte

Name: Vaccinium myrtillus
Comment on life form: dwarf shrub

Name: Vaccinium uliginosum
Comment on life form: dwarf shrub

Name: Vaccinium vitis-idaea
Comment on life form: dwarf shrub

Name: Euphorbia peplis
Source for max height: 1/3 average of stem length in Butcher (1961) and Stace (191)

Name: Lathyrus latifolius
Comment on life form: MOH suspects that it is geophyte
Comment on clonality: Clonal spread short by distance 'phalanx' (J. Ecol. 80: 555-565 1992)

Name: Lathyrus linifolius
Comment on life form: geoo (Aesch & Burdet, 1994)
Comment on clonality: Rhizome system is tuberous

Name: Lathyrus palustris
Comment on life form: MOH suspects that it is geophyte
Comment on clonality: Extent of underground spread needs checking

Name: Lathyrus pratensis
Comment on life form: MOH suspects that it is geophyte
Comment on clonality: Authors of CPE say rhizome can be 7 m long

Name: Lathyrus sylvestris
Comment on life form: MOH suspects that it is geophyte
Comment on clonality: Clonal spread short by distance 'phalanx' (J. Ecol. 80: 555-565 1992)

Name: Medicago lupulina
Comment on life form: The books say annual or short-lived perennial

Name: Medicago sativa
Comment on clonality: The indigenous form falcata is shortly creeping

Name: Melilotus albus
Comment on life form: The books say annual or biennial; given its size, I guess biennial more common

Name: Vicia cracca
Comment on clonality: Indicated as highly mobile by Tamm et al. (2002) but having limited spread by CPE

Name: Vicia sativa
Source for max height: Stace (1991) - ave of ssp. nigra, segetalis

Name: Vicia sepium
Comment on clonality: Indicated as highly mobile by Tamm et al. (2002) but having limited spread by CPE

Name: Vicia sylvatica
Comment on clonality: Clonal according to Clopla1; British information not available

Name: Geranium robertianum
Comment on life form: CTW & Stace say "annual or biennial"

Name: Hypericum hirsutum
Comment on clonality: only limited capacity for vegetative reproduction (CPE)

Name: Hypericum perforatum
Comment on clonality: root-budding mainly in shallow soils (CPE)

Name: Origanum vulgare
Comment on life form: genuinely intermediate; dies back to well below 25 cm in winter
Comment on clonality: Creeps slowly when grown in flowerbed; also in grass when mown

Name: Pinguicula vulgaris
Comment on clonality: Regularly forms bulbils, averaging only 2 per year; not clear whether these are the main method of reproduction (Heslop-Harrison, Biol. Flora 2004)

Name: Linum catharticum
Comment on life form: According to P J Grubb (pers. comm.) never annual; the books are wrong.

Name: Tilia cordata x platyphyllos (T. x europaea)
Lysimachia nummularia
Comment on life form: classified as Anagallis tenella

Name: Nymphaea alba
Source for max height: Water depth given by Preston & Croft (1997)

Name: Nuphar lutea
Source for max height: Water depth for floating lvs, estimated by MOH

Name: Epilobium palustre
Comment on clonality: Rhizomes produce shoots often more than 10 cm from parent

Name: Platanthera bifolia
Source for max height: 10 cm less than P. chlorantha, as in CTW (1962)

Name: Parnassia palustris
Source for max height: Butcher (1961); also blade 5 cm, petiole longer than blade (CTW)

Name: Plantago lanceolata
Comment on clonality: Underground stems longer-lasting than Bellis; Clopla1 also suggests that produces buds on roots

Name: Veronica chamaedrys
Comment on life form: intermediate; overwinters pretty close to the ground

Name: Veronica spicata
Comment on life form: dies back to creeping stems; closer to hemicryptophyte

Name: Rumex aquaticus
Comment on life form: a semi-rosette hemicryptophyte

Name: Potamogeton pusillus
Comment on clonality: Turions either axillary or (in autumn) terminal

Name: Zannichellia palustris
Source for max height: CTW (1962) = average of Sell & Murrell (1996) and Butcher (1961)

Name: Glaux maritima
Comment on life form: a geophytic pseudoannual in Baltic area (Jerling 1988); is it ever hemicryptophyte?
Comment on clonality: Yapp et al., J. Ecol. 5, p.77, 1917; Jerling, Vegetatio 74, 171-185

Name: Lysimachia nummularia
Comment on life form: classified as Anagallis tenella

Name: Primula farinosa
Comment on clonality: Nearly 13, a 'bulb hemicryptophyte' forming small clones (Hambler, D., BSBI News, 93, 39-42, 2003)

Name: Ranunculus auricomus
Comment on life form: not obvious why CTW treat it as sometimes a geophyte

Name: Ranunculus ficaria
Comment on clonality: not much spread by tubers unless ground is dug or disturbed

Name: Alchemilla vulgaris agg.
Source for max height: average of all except A. alpina

Name: Filipendula vulgaris
Comment on life form: Said to regenerate from toot tubers (MOH has not verified)

Name: Rosa mollis
Comment on clonality: somewhat suckering (CTW), suckering and when conditions are favourable forming dense thickets (BSBI Hbk)

Name: Galium aparine
Source for max height: Aeschimann & Burdet (1994) - CTW (1962) too low, Stace (1997) too high

Name: Galium boreale
Comment on clonality: Sell (draft) says "with rooting stolons"; Clopla1 indicates that rhizomes long-lived

Name: Galium odoratum
Comment on life form: best treatedas a rhizomatous hemicryptophyte

Name: Saxifraga granulata
Comment on life form: produces bulbils; perhaps to some extent a bulbil-therophyte

Name: Linaria repens
Comment on clonality: Clopla1 says that produces buds on roots; not indicated in GB floras

Name: Linaria vulgaris
Comment on clonality: spreading by root buds but not very extensively (CPE); but probably enough to be 62

Name: Solanum dulcamara
Comment on life form: normally too big to count as a chamaephyte, but prostrate forms are known
Comment on clonality: clones formed by rooting stems (CPE and personal observation); Clopla1 suggests root-budding;

Name: Viola hirta
Comment on clonality: Slow vegetative spread by branching rhizome (CPE)

Name: Viola palustris
Source for max height: Aeschimann & Burdet (1994) - British floras not giving height

Name: Viola riviniana
Comment on clonality: root-sprouting in some plants, implying that not all can do it (CPE)

Name: Viola tricolor
Comment on life form: Ssp. tricolor, which is annual, is much the commonest
